page.title: 10Transport-canal and rail
page.content: The Grand Union Canal, opened in 1800, passes through Leighton/Linslade. It was built for conveying coal from Braunston Junction to London. The railway soon replaced the canal for haulage. This year enthusiasts have transported 200 tons of coal(6 boats) through Linslade but the majority of the 4540 boat movements were for leisure purposes. Leighton/Linslade has a main-line railway station. The electrified railway links Glasgow and Manchester to London and was built in 1839, for the haulage of coal. It also carried sand quarried from this area. The train and the geological deposits in the area are the main factors responsible for the growth of the town. Many commuters live in the town, some 2750 people using the 113 train which stop at the station daily.
